description.short: Methodology for making product decisions based on explicit, documented principles rather than intuition, enabling faster, more consistent, and defensible choices
description.detailed: Product Management Decision Framework is a structured approach to decision-making where teams define explicit principles (criteria) upfront, then evaluate options against these principles systematically. Instead of debating endlessly or relying on gut feel, PMs document decision criteria (e.g., 'prioritize features that reduce time-to-value', 'avoid lock-in', 'optimize for learning over perfection'), score options, and make defensible choices with clear rationale. This methodology is especially valuable for recurring decision types (feature prioritization, build vs. buy, roadmap sequencing) where establishing principles once enables faster, more consistent decisions over time. Advanced practitioners create 'decision templates' for common scenarios.
description.primary_function: Enable faster, more consistent, and better-documented product decisions through explicit principle-based evaluation
key_capabilities: Document decision rationale for stakeholder alignment
Create reusable decision templates for recurring scenarios
Enable delegation by clarifying decision criteria
Align teams on shared values and priorities

key_concepts.description: Document decision criteria clearly rather than relying on unstated assumptions or intuition
key_concepts.benefit: Enables alignment, delegation, and retrospective learning

key_concepts.description: Define 'what matters' (principles) rather than 'how to decide' (rigid process)
key_concepts.benefit: Flexible adaptation to context while maintaining consistency

key_concepts.description: Optimize for learning per unit of effort, not just velocity or output
key_concepts.benefit: Compounds over time; builds institutional knowledge

key_concepts.description: Make good-enough decisions quickly with clear rationale rather than pursuing elusive perfect choice
Invest in decision templates for recurring scenarios rather than starting from scratch each time
key_concepts.benefit: Scales decision quality across team and time

use_cases.title: Feature Prioritization with Explicit Criteria
use_cases.description: Define principles (e.g., user impact, strategic value, implementation cost, risk) and score feature candidates systematically
use_cases.user_persona: Product managers, product leaders, engineering managers

use_cases.title: Build vs. Buy Decisions
use_cases.description: Establish criteria (cost, time-to-market, strategic differentiation, maintenance burden) and evaluate options objectively

use_cases.title: Experiment Design and Hypotheses
use_cases.description: Apply 'learning rate over activity rate' principle to prioritize experiments by learning value, not just ease
use_cases.user_persona: Growth PMs, data scientists, experimentation teams

use_cases.title: Stakeholder Alignment on Trade-offs
use_cases.description: Document decision principles to explain trade-off choices to stakeholders transparently

use_cases.title: Delegate Decisions with Confidence
use_cases.description: Share decision principles with team members so they can make consistent choices without constant PM approval
use_cases.user_persona: Product leaders, senior PMs, team leads

step_1.name: Define Decision Type
step_1.description: Identify recurring decision pattern (e.g., feature prioritization, vendor selection, roadmap sequencing)

step_2.name: Establish Principles/Criteria
step_2.description: Brainstorm what matters for this decision type; prioritize 3-7 key principles

step_3.name: Score Options
step_3.description: Evaluate each option against principles; assign scores
step_3.method: Scorecard, decision matrix, or weighted rubric

step_4.name: Make Decision with Rationale
step_4.description: Select option based on scores; document why this choice aligns with principles

step_5.name: Create Reusable Template (Optional)
step_5.description: If this decision type recurs, save principles as template for future use

step_6.name: Retrospective Review
step_6.description: After 3-6 months, review: did principles hold? Would we change criteria?

learning_curve.advanced_usage: 1-2 months (build library of decision templates, delegate effectively)

quality_improvements: 80% reduction in decision reversal rate (better initial choices)
60% more consistent decisions across team (shared principles)
90% improved decision documentation (explicit vs. tribal knowledge)
team_value: Enables delegation (team can decide without PM bottleneck)
Faster onboarding (new PMs learn decision principles)
roi_metrics.value_proposition: Compounds over time; initial investment in defining principles pays dividends on every future decision of that type

principle_definition: Start with 3-5 principles (expand only if needed)
Make principles specific and measurable (avoid vague 'quality')
Test principles on past decisions (would they have led to good outcomes?)
Revisit principles quarterly (do they still reflect priorities?)
application: Document decision rationale in writing (memo, doc, Notion page)
Share decision template with team for reuse
Use scorecard/matrix format for visual clarity
Discuss principles in decision meetings (not just scores)
Acknowledge when intuition disagrees with scores (investigate why)
Archive decisions for future reference (learning library)
team_adoption: Start with one high-frequency decision type (e.g., feature prioritization)
Co-create principles with team (buy-in through collaboration)
Share examples of decisions made with framework (show value)
Refine principles based on team feedback
Integrate into existing workflows (don't add separate process)

known_limitations: Requires upfront time to define principles (investment before payoff)
Not suitable for one-off, unique decisions (overkill)
Principles may become outdated as strategy shifts
Can feel rigid if applied dogmatically (balance with judgment)
Requires cultural buy-in (won't work if team prefers gut decisions)
limitations.best_for: Teams with recurring decision types, distributed decision-making, need for alignment/delegation, growing product teams
limitations.not_ideal_for: One-off strategic pivots, highly exploratory phases, very small teams (overhead not justified)
